awd_titl_txt: GP EXTRA: Engaging Students in the Geosciences Using a Lake Watershed Geosystems Path
awd_abstract_narration:
In response to national and state concerns, New Hampshire?s public systems of higher education set a goal of a 50% increase in STEM graduates by 2020 and to double that by 2025. Recruiting, retaining, and graduating undergraduate students in STEM disciplines, like geoscience, is a major challenge especially at Predominantly Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs). The Lake Watershed Geosystems Path (LWGP) directly responds to these local and regional mandates while helping meet national needs to augment the geoscience trained workforce. Students learn scientific concepts quicker and more permanently when the concepts are provided as relevant applications. This project uses this educational principle of a problem-based, field-intensive, applied interdisciplinary science approach and seamlessly scaffolds it into existing curriculum and research opportunities. It also includes faculty and peer mentoring and links participants to applied geoscience internships and career opportunities. 

The Lake Watershed Geosystems Path (LWGP) project seeks to increase STEM preparation and graduates in the following ways: 1) partnering with the Plymouth State University Admissions to recruit a diverse cohort of first-year students in STEM fields, 2) encouraging participating students to enroll in a newly created first-year seminar course that develops critical thinking through a geoscience lens, 3) engaging students in extracurricular field- and lab-based research as part of a new PSU Cluster project which spans the major hydrological components of watershed systems, including atmospheric deposition, land surface runoff, stream flow, and resulting effects on lake basins, and 4) assisting participating students in entering into pre-arranged internships and externships which leverage their newly acquired geoscience training. LWGP alumni will be recruited to help peer mentor and train subsequent participants via a 1-credit independent study elective. Ultimately, LWGP will blend field and laboratory student experiences oriented around hydrologic pathways in lake watersheds with community partnerships and faculty/peer mentoring to: 1) introduce geoscience principles, systems thinking and skill development at the onset of student university experiences; 2) increase student retention and success in non-geoscience degree programs that serve as pathways into geoscience fields; 3) foster strong cohort identification, and 4) apply knowledge and skills gained by students in this project to enhance their future work experiences, education goals, and career objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From 2018-2022, Plymouth State University, a predominantly undergraduate institution with no geology program but strong B.S. and M.S. programs in meteorology and environmental science ran a GeoPaths EXTRA project "Engaging Students in the Geosciences Using  a Lake Watershed Geosystems Path" aimed at building critical thinking and technical skills beneficial in geoscience careers. We recruited cohorts of up to 12 first-year college students enrolled in Environmental Science and Meteorology majors and introduced them, via field trips, mini-projects and workshops, invited speakers and internships to workforce skills like research design, monitoring instrumentation, and data analysis.

Evaluation of the project overall reveals that the mentoring efforts of the faculty involved in this project, in concert with the students' activities, were highly effective in increasing retention among the predominantly White students, and their academic success (GPA scores) in the years of school after their GeoPaths engagement. The project activities alone were not enough to prevent disengagement and departure from the school by Black and Hispanic project participants.

COVID-19 forced the 2019-20 cohort to delay internships by a year or two, and student participants initially presented with withdrawal and stress. We increased our contact with the students to weekly, with group Zoom meetings, and adapted the GeoPaths program to take advantage of remote technology to increase our mentor diversity. We invited a diverse set of speakers who are now well-established in their careers, to meet with the students and share their stories, including their unexpected paths into a geoscience career.

The disruption of the pandemic, and rapid implementation of remote meeting technologies also created opportunity to develop a supplemental OPEN STEM project (MEERCAP) that adds climate mitigation instrumentation, monitoring and education to the GeoPaths project. With this new infrastructure, GeoPath students learned a wide variety of hands-on skills, including how to work with wood, nuts and bolts, electrical wires and glass. They also learned the process, and challenges, of transferring an idea into a drawing and plan and then into a field installation. The next-generation of this project is a multi-institutional effort that brings together in-service teachers, K-12 educators, citizen scientists, university and college students, and the local community in exploration of a ground-based, low-cost climate mitigation project involving mirrors to reflect sunlight back to space and decrease Earth's potential for warming.

Direct learning outcomes of the GeoPaths project includes applied use of physics, geometry, surveying, programming, electronics and science communication, as well as excitement about the diverse array of careers open to them in the geosciences.
